Graphical abstract Fe incorporated mesocellular foam catalysts (FeMCFs) developed by direct synthesis method were characterized and catalytic degradation of acid red B dye (ARB) via Fenton-like reaction was demonstrated. The shape and particle sizes of FeMCF changed significantly with an increase in the Fe concentration (4–12wt.%) accompanied with the formation of Fe particles agglomerated on the external surface of the catalysts. Interestingly, the sponge-like foam structure coupled with large pores of MCF could be maintained for all concentrations of Fe added. FT-IR and UV–vis DRS analyses revealed that Fe was successfully incorporated mostly within the mesostructure of MCF rather than being distributed on the external surface at Fe loadings of 4–10wt.%. However, formation of minor amount of iron oxides distributed on the external surface of FeMCF12 was detected by the appearance of broad bands in the range of 300–400nm. An increase in the Fe content (4–12wt.%) gave a slight decrease in the surface area (708–606m2/g) and pore properties of the FeMCF. The increase in the Fe concentration from 4 to 12wt.% progressively increased the degradation from 63 to 100%. The high decolourisation and degradation efficiencies of FeMCF10 could be explained in terms of combined factors such as high mesopore surface area (552m2/g), large cell size (8nm) and the presence of isolated Fe species leading to high accessibility of active sites without mass transfer limitations. FeMCF10 exhibited long term stability and good structural stability after it was used for five consecutive degradation cycles. Keywords Mesocellular foam Fe loading Catalysts characteristics Catalytic degradation Catalyst reusability 1 Introduction Water pollution by dye compounds is an increasing concern in many countries worldwide due to the negative short term and long term effects on human, other life forms and environment [1]. One of the potential solutions to solve this problem is the use of simple Fenton-like process based on iron solid catalyst. This process involves the generation of both hydroxyl (OH) and perhydroxyl radicals (OOH) from the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) by Fe2⁺ or Fe3⁺ ions [2]. Basically, the important requirement for the development of heterogeneous catalyst for organic compounds degradation is the presence of a suitable porous support. This is to provide higher metal dispersion within the support without causing significant formation of aggregated catalyst particles. Of the developed support materials, Fe loading zeolites [3,4] and clays [5,6] have been investigated as solid catalysts in the degradation of organic dyes. Even though a relatively good degradation efficiencies were successfully achieved [7–10], the exact roles of the heterogeneous catalyst are still unclear. This is because, only the Fe species that is dispersed on the external surface of the catalyst could take part in the degradation process. Therefore, the advantages of having good features of the support material will not be achieved if the problems related to leaching and aggregation of the active components are not resolved. As a result, the high efficiencies only limited to the degradation of the organic pollutants but very poor mineralization efficiencies and catalyst reusability performance are achieved. In order to overcome the current weaknesses of heterogeneous Fenton-like catalyst, this study addresses the development of mesocellular foam (MCF) to form a supported catalyst. MCF was originally synthesized in 1999 by modifying the structure of SBA-15 in the presence of swelling agent [11]. A combination of soft-templating and hydrothermal method are used for the synthesis of MCF materials [12]. The structure is sponge-like form and the pores could be accessed in three-dimensional (3D) way unlike mesoporous channels of SBA-15 which are accessible from one dimension only [13]. The uniqueness of this material could be seen from its large pore sizes and short mesochannels that are large enough to accommodate a variety of large molecules to favour the mass transfer of large molecules within the pores where the active metal is located. Thus, it is expected that the incorporation of active species within its structure can be possibly carried out with less occurrence of pore blockages. So, the interaction between the active metal and reactants (H2O2 and dye) could be efficiently achieved. From the green chemistry point of view, due to the excellent properties of this material, the maximum usage could be achieved for many times without experiencing a drastic deactivation that could lead to poor reusability performance. Plus, this material is thought to be very promising to be applied in water and wastewater treatment since the presence of it does not contribute to serious harmful effects on the environment. However, it should be noted that reports on the use of MCF as a catalyst support for catalytic degradation of organic pollutants are hardly found. Therefore, further improvement and modification in MCF supported catalysts are vital in enhancing the efficiency of the treatment process. In this study, an attempt has been made to investigate the influence of Fe concentration (4–12wt.%) to be incorporated into MCF on the characteristics of the catalyst to be subsequently applied for catalytic degradation of acid red B dye (ARB). Previously, the incorporation of active metal into MCF is mostly carried out using post synthesis methods (impregnation and post grafting) [14]. However, the inherent drawbacks of those methods could lead to the undesired properties of the catalyst. Therefore, direct synthesis method has been chosen to incorporate Fe into MCF. This method become very attractive as the direct incorporation of heteroatom into the silica structure led to the formation of a more stable metal species and in an economic point of view, this method could shorten the time of synthesis process. Further investigation on this particular effect is important in order to determine the most suitable amount of Fe that should be incorporated to give not just high catalytic activity but also could maintain its catalytic performance. In fact, different concentrations of Fe added during the synthesis may lead to different characteristics of the developed catalysts. Thus, the possible interaction and attachment of metal species into MCF will be different. Finally, the stability and reusability potential of the catalyst have also been explored. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and chemicals Tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS), 1, 3, 5—trimethylbenzene (TMB) and poly (ethylene glycol)-B-poly (propylene G) (P123) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich and they were used in this study as a silica source, a swelling agent and a soft template, respectively. Iron (III) nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3.9H2O), hydrochloric acid (HCl) (37%), hydrogen peroxide, 30% (H2O2), sodium hydroxide (NaOH) were purchased from Merck Sdn. Bhd. while acid red B dye (ARB) was purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Finally, double distilled water was used throughout this study for dilution and washing purposes. 2.2 Synthesis of Fe incorporated MCF catalysts by direct synthesis method A soft-templating hydrothermal method was employed to synthesize Fe incorporated MCF catalysts and the basic ingredients were adopted from Miao et al. [15] with some modifications. First, 8g of P123 was dissolved in 150ml of HCl (1.5M) for 5min under vigorous stirring. Then, 6g of TMB was added and the mixture was continuously stirred for another 4h. Before the addition of 4wt.% of Fe, the solution pH was adjusted to 2.3. The solution was then stirred for 30min before the addition of TEOS and the mixture was continuously stirred for 24h at 40°C. The resulting solution was then aged in an oven at a 80°C and maintained in static condition for 24h. The sample was then filtered using vacuum filter and dried in an oven at 100°C for another 24 before subjecting to a heat treatment at 500°C for 6h. The preparation steps were repeated for Fe concentrations of 8, 10 and 12wt.%. The FeMCF obtained are denoted as FeMCF4, FeMCF8, FeMCF10 and FeMCF12 to indicate the weight percentages of Fe incorporated into the MCF. 2.3 Characterization of the developed FeMCF FeMCF developed with different Fe concentrations were characterized using SEM-EDX, TEM, UV–vis DRS, FT-IR and surface analysis methods. SEM (model Philips XL30S) was employed to study the effect of different Fe concentrations towards the surface structures. TEM (Model Soft Imaging System, SIS 3.0) was employed to investigate the distribution of Fe species within the pore structure of the developed catalysts. In order to check whether Fe incorporated within the MCF structure was in the form of crystalline iron oxide or isolated metal, a UV–vis DRS (Perkin Elmer Lambda 35) was used with magnesium oxide (MgO) as the reference. In the meantime, FT-IR (Shimadzu IR Prestige-21) was employed to determine the functional groups to confirm for any possible interaction between the Fe species and MCF structure. Meanwhile, the pore size distribution, BET surface area and total pore volume were measured directly based on N2 physisorption using a Micromeritics ASAP 2000 system operated at 77K. In the meantime, the cell and window sizes were determined based on BJH adsorption-desorption method [15]. 2.4 Catalytic activity of FeMCF in the degradation of azo dye First, 0.1g/L of FeMCF with different Fe concentrations (FeMCF4, FeMCF8, FeMCF10 and FeMCF12) was mixed with 100ml of ARB at an initial concentration of 100mg/L in a glass reactor. The initial pH of the solution was fixed at 3.2 while the temperature of the solution was maintained throughout the reaction at 30°C. A preliminary study showed that the adsorption efficiency of ARB on the catalyst did not change significantly after 15 to 60min of mixing. Therefore, the catalyst was allowed to disperse in the dye solution for only 15min in the absence of H2O2 in order to determine the adsorption capability of the developed catalyst. After that, 9mM of hydrogen peroxide (30% H2O2) was added into the mixture solution to initiate the reaction. The concentration of ARB at time (t) was determined for every 15min for 60min of reaction. 2.5 Analysis of liquid sample The dye concentrations was monitored by sampling at regular time intervals and analysed using a UV–vis spectrophotometer (Agilent Cary 60). The concentration of the treated sample was measured at a wavelength of 507nm. The final concentration of ARB was calculated based on Eq. (1) and the extent of ARB degradation was measured using Eq. (2). Meanwhile, the reaction rates were tested using the apparent-first-order and second order kinetic models as shown in Eqs. (3) and (4), respectively. An open reflux method was used for COD measurement where 2ml of the treated sample was added into the high range COD reagent (50–1500mg/L). The COD value was determined by means of a calorimeter (Hach DRB 200) and the COD removal during the reaction was calculated based on Eq. (5). Meanwhile, the TOC removal was determined using Eq. (6). (1) Final ARB concentration ( mg/L ) = Co − Ct (2) Degradation of ARB ( % ) = ( Co − Ct/Co ) × 100 % (3) Pseudo first order, l n Ct Co = − k t (4) Pseudo second order, 1 Ct − 1 Co = k t (5) % COD removal = COD o − COD t COD t × 100 % (6) % TOC removal = TOC o − TOC t TOC o × 100 % After the reaction was completed, the treated solution was separated from the solid particles. Then, the clear supernatant was checked using an atomic absorption spectrometer (AAS) to determine the amount of Fe leaching. The detection of OH was made based on the conversion of terephthalate (TA) into the strongly fluorescent 2-hydroxyterephthalic acid (HTA). The solution of TA was prepared according to the standard protocols adopted from Cao et al. [16]. The formation of HTA could be observed on the PL signal of 425nm by means of a spectrofluorometer (PerkinElmer Lambda S55). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of FeMCF 3.1.1 SEM SEM images of FeMCF are presented in Fig. 1 (a)–(d) and the image of MCF support is shown in Fig. 1(e) for comparison. FeMCF4 appeared as a slightly white powder but with further increase in the Fe content from 8 to 12wt.%, the catalyst particles were visibly transformed to brownish colour. Fig. 1(a) shows that the incorporation of 4wt.% of Fe caused agglomeration of spheres to form longer particles with larger sizes. Further increase in the Fe content to 8wt.% apparently changed the particle shapes in which the formation of more rounded particles in aggregated form was observed. In addition, the presence of small amount of impurities is clearly observed on the external surface of FeMCF8. On the other hand, at 10wt.% of Fe, the particle shape and size were apparently altered. In fact, the outer surface of FeMCF10 was made up of a uniform deposition of tiny particles and this observation could be attributed to an excess amount of Fe that failed to be incorporated within the corona part of the micelle [7]. It indicates that Fe could have fully covered the surface of the catalyst as the concentration was too high and it might not be incorporated evenly within the MCF framework [17]. Thus, it was forced to be deposited on the external surface of catalyst. Further increase in the Fe concentration to 12wt.% led to an obvious change in the particle shape as the formation of irregular shapes and sizes of catalyst particles was detected. An increment by 2wt.% from the previous loading suggests that further reduction in the pH of the synthesis solution slightly minimized the possibility for Fe species to be fully incorporated into the MCF structure. Therefore, the formation of large number of coarse particles and an increase in the surface roughness deposited on the external surface of FeMCF12 were clearly observed and they could be attributed to the iron oxide aggregates [5].Based on the EDX result (data not shown), an increase in the Fe concentration added into MCF structure resulted in a slight increase in the peak attributed to the presence of Fe. However, for FeMCF4 and FeMCF8, no appearance of Fe species could be detected. Thus, it could be assumed that a smooth and almost clear surface demonstrated by FeMCF4 and good distribution of tiny particles dispersed on the surface of FeMCF8 were probably due to the successful attachment of Fe species located within the MCF framework or pore channels. Moreover, the detection of small peaks by EDX analysis for FeMCF10 and more intense Fe peaks for FeMCF12 proved that only small amount of Fe was evenly distributed on the external surface of the catalyst. 3.1.2 TEM TEM images shown in Fig. 1(f)–(h) provide pictorial evidences for the formation of the good dispersion of FeMCF catalyst and (i) MCF support as reference. As shown in Fig. 1(f), no appearance of any darker spots attributed to the presence of Fe could be observed in FeMCF4. However, the typical mesostructure and large pores of MCF could still be maintained to indicate that a low concentration of Fe added did not significantly affect the structure as the possibility for the metal to agglomerate was rather low. Thus, instead of forming large aggregates of particles within the pore channels or on the external surface of the catalyst, the Fe species was thought to have been distributed evenly within the MCF structure. However, a slight improvement was observed for FeMCF8 in which the formation of clear darker spots was visibly identified within the large pore channels of MCF and also intercalated within the MCF framework. Thus, the increase in the Fe concentration from 4 to 8wt.% evidently improved the Fe attachment within the MCF framework and pore channels. Further increase in the Fe concentration to 10 and 12wt.% resulted in a quite similar observation as the appearance of intense and darker spots could be easily identified. By looking at the textural properties for both FeMCF10 and FeMCF12 (Fig. 1(g,h)), a clear formation of Fe species was preferentially located within the large pores of MCF and embedded within the silica framework. It should be noted that in the acidic medium, the reduction in the solution pH after the incorporating of larger amount of Fe might decrease the possibility for the Fe and silica to form SiOMOSi linkages [18]. Therefore, the formation of iron oxide nanoparticles mainly occurred on the external surface or along the large pore channels of the catalyst at Fe loading of 12wt.%. However, the typical large mesostructure of MCF could still be observed to indicate that highly acidic pH of the synthesis solution could help in maintaining the mesostructure. Moreover, these images also confirm that Fe species was well distributed within the pore channels as no patches of MCF structured damage are found for the samples analyzed compared to the work reported previously by Tomer et al. [19]. 3.1.3 N2 adsorption-desorption measurement For further understanding of the dependence of pore structures of FeMCF materials on the variation in the Fe loading, N2 sorption isotherms of the corresponding samples were performed and the results are presented in Fig. 2 . All the developed FeMCF possess isotherms of type IV with hysteresis loops of Type H2 to indicate that the FeMCF had an ink-bottle types of mesostructure in which the size of the cell was significantly larger than the size of the window for all the catalysts. An increase in the Fe concentration resulted in slight changes in the BET surface area, pore volume and window/cell size. As tabulated in Table 1 , FeMCF4 gave the largest surface area with largest pore volume and cell size with 708m2/g, 1.387cm3/g and 10nm, respectively. However, as the Fe concentration was further increased to 8wt.%, a slight decrease in the surface area by 69m2/g, a reduction in the pore volume to 1.124cm3/g while virtually unchanged cell size of 10nm were observed to indicate that Fe species could have been distributed within the silica framework and along the pore channels [20]. Conversely, a slight increase in the surface area was detected for FeMCF10 (671m2/g) but with a slight decrease in the pore volume (1.029cm3/g) and cell size (8nm). The increase in the surface area with the increment of 2wt.% of Fe loading might be contributed by the formation of mesopores due to the deposition of Fe species. Thus, it would directly create a new porous structure to the enhancement of the surface area. This statement could be supported by the results of mesopore surface area as it was found to increase to 552m2/g for FeMCF10 compared to 493m2/g for FeMCF8. Meanwhile, decreases in the pore volume and cell size signify that Fe might have been distributed not just in the MCF structure but also in the large pores of MCF. The pore volume also experienced a decrease with the increase in the Fe content. This phenomenon could be possibly due to partial blockages of micropores/mesopores that were caused by aggregated iron oxide species [21]. However, reductions in the values of micropores/mesopores were observed as the Fe content was increased from 4 to 10wt.%. The values showed drastic increases when the Fe concentration reached 12wt.%. According to Aktas et al. [22] the corona part of the MCF micelle represents the micropores while the cores part represents the mesopores. Therefore, as the values of micropore area and volume dramatically decreased with the increase in the Fe content to 10wt.%, it was proven that Fe3⁺ had been successfully embedded within the corona part of the micelle to consequently diminish the area and volume of the micropores. It could have built up along the mesopores channels to consequently minimize the cell size. Sun et al [21] suggested that the reduction in the pore volume with the increase in the Fe concentration might occur due to the strong interaction between metal ions and surface hydroxyl groups. Further increase in the Fe concentration to 12wt.% resulted in a detrimental effect towards the surface area as it reduced to 606m2/g which was the lowest surface area among all the developed catalysts. This phenomenon could be due to the intercalation of metal species within MCF framework [19] and aggregation along the short pore channels and external surface of the catalyst. Moreover, due to the formation of coarse particles on the external surface of FeMCF12 (as shown by SEM analysis), the possibility for the pores to be blocked was relatively high to directly cause a reduction in the pore volume leading to a reduction in the surface area. However, it is interesting to note that no obvious reduction/change in the BET surface area was observed as the Fe concentration was increased to higher amount compared to the results reported previously by Budhi et al. [23] Su et al. [24] and Widyaningrum et al. [14]. This was due to the specifically large pore of MCF structure so that it was capable to incorporate the metal uniformly even at high metal loadings. Another possible reason could be due to the direct method of incorporating Fe into MCF structure as it could possibly minimize the severe pore blockage as the Fe tend to be distributed evenly either on the inside of the structure or along the pore channels. Even though for some cases, the agglomeration of Fe was found to occur on the external surface of the catalyst, it was not so severe to the extent that significant change in the catalyst properties was detected. By varying the Fe contents, the size of the window of FeMCF4 and FeMCF8 became significantly smaller compared to the size of the cell with the ratio of 3/10 and 3/9nm, respectively. It might have occurred due to the tendency of Fe species to be deposited on or along the window of the MCF structure rather than being distributed within the cell structure. Meanwhile, as the Fe concentration was increased to 10 and 12wt.%, the difference in the ratio of cell/window size was not too obvious in which they showed a ratio of 8/4 and 9/4nm, respectively. This observation could be due to the tendency for the Fe species to be deposited mostly within the MCF framework and within the cell of the catalyst. Therefore, as the cell area was deposited by the Fe species, the sizes were getting smaller due to the built up of Fe species to consequently cause no significant difference in the window size. In a previous study, Zhang et al. [25] recommended that an increase in the pore size after metal incorporation into SBA-15 structure was possibly due to the substitution of the metal species embedded within the silica structure of the support material. However, when the pore size of the catalyst decreased at higher metal loadings, the metal could not possibly be situated within the support structure only but it could be relatively distributed along the pore channels. Similar opinion was shared by Hu et al. [26]. In this study, the cell size of the catalyst decreased with the increase in the Fe loading. Thus, it could be assumed that the decrease in the cell size after Fe loading might be due to the attachment of Fe species to the MCF structure on the surface hydroxyl groups as proposed by Zhang et al. [25] Sun et al. [21] and Zhang et al. [17]. As a result, it would contract the pore wall when combined with two or more hydroxyl groups which consequently contributed to a slight decrease in the cell size after the increase in the Fe loading so that it was deposited mostly on the surface of cell or window of the catalyst. Moreover, the tendency for the high amount of Fe to be distributed mostly within the cell caused a reduction in the size of the cell to be comparable with FeMCF4 that had low amount of Fe. On the other hand, the window size of the developed catalyst obviously increased with the increase in the Fe concentration from 4 to 12wt.%. This observation could be possibly due to the entrapment of Fe species within the MCF framework. The large cell of catalyst could provide enough space for the reactant to reach to the active sites that were located within the cell. In conjunction with that, a suitable size of window is also important in allowing the reactant to diffuse into the cell and to allow the intermediates to desorb back to the bulk solution. 3.1.4 UV–vis DRS FeMCF was further characterized by UV–vis DRS analysis in order to detect the presence of Fe species and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . Basically, absorption bands below 300nm can be attributed to the presence of isolated iron species and those between 300nm and 400nm should be attributed to iron oxide nanoclusters. Meanwhile, bulk iron oxide exhibits the absorption band between 400nm and 600nm [27]. At lower concentrations of Fe in FeMCF4 and FeMCF8, broad peaks below 300nm are observed. They could be assigned to t1→t2 and t1 →e transitions involving Fe3⁺ in [FeO4] − tetrahedral [28,29]. When the Fe concentrations was increased to 10wt.%, an intense adsorption peak at wavelengths below 300nm slowly sharpens and shifted to the blue region (lower wavelength). This indicates that isolated iron species did exist mostly in the MCF framework for the FeMCF10 samples [27,30]. Meanwhile, Mendoza-Nieto et al. [31] suggested that a blue shift occurred after the addition of higher Fe concentration could be due to an increase in the dispersion of metal species in the support material. However, further increase in the Fe content to 12wt.% significantly decreases the sharpness of the band as the formation of broad and wide band is observed. This result signifies that majority of the Fe species might have failed to incorporate into MCF structure at high Fe loading. It should be noted that no broad band appears for FeMCF4, FeMCF8 and FeMCF10 at a region higher than 300nm. This is to indicate that the Fe-containing MCF catalysts were indeed free from aggregated iron oxide clusters [32,33]. Moreover, it could be due to the limited amount of Fe added in FeMCF4, FeMCF8 and high dispersion for FeMCF10. Meanwhile, the appearance of a very broad band between 350 and 400nm for FeMCF12 suggests the existence of small portion of iron oxides crystalline particles on the external surface of catalyst. This observation was in line with the SEM results as the formation of Fe species on the external surface of the catalyst was only clearly observed in the case of FeMCF12. However, no peaks corresponding to iron oxides crystalline could be detected from XRD analysis (data not shown) even for catalysts with high Fe concentrations such as FeMCF12. This observation suggests that the distribution of nanocrystallite iron oxides on the external surface of the catalyst was highly dispersed to hinder its detection in the XRD analysis [17]. 3.1.5 FT-IR In order to have better understanding on the physicochemical characteristics of the developed catalysts, FT-IR analysis was carried out and the spectra for FeMCF developed with various Fe concentrations are presented in Fig. 4 . In the finger print region (400–1200cm−1), the peaks at 457, 802 and 1085cm−1 are typical to SiOSi vibrations of silica framework [34]. Upon increasing the Fe concentration from 4 to 12wt.%, small shifts to lower frequencies are observed for FeMCF8 and FeMCF10. However, no changes are detected for FeMCF4 and FeMCF12. These results provide strong evidences that the incorporated Fe species could have structurally combined with MCF structure for FeMCF8 and FeMCF10 [35]. FeMCF12 contained the highest amount of Fe compared to the other catalysts. However, the Fe species did not necessary combine chemically with Si. In a previous study by Shukla et al. [36]. a small shoulder was found at a wavenumber of 586cm−1 and this signal is attributed to the presence of spinal CoO bonding, suggesting the presence of small quantity of cobalt oxide crystallites on the surface of SBA—15as a supported catalyst. However, no intensed peak at 586cm−1 could be detected on the FT-IR spectra for FeMCF12 to indicate the absence of any formation of crystallite iron oxide. This result was in accordance with the UV–vis DRS analysis in which only a small broad band is noted for FeMCF12. This observation might be due to the low amount of iron oxides or else, the peak might be too small relative to the other peaks to hinder it from appearing in the FT-IR spectra. Meanwhile, the broad bands centred at about 3400cm−1 in all silica based materials represent the hydroxyl vibrations, which could be due to the presence of hydroxyl groups of adsorbed water molecules [37]. Meanwhile the band at 1620cm−1 is generally ascribed to bending vibration of adsorbed water [34]. By comparing the FT-IR spectra for all the developed catalysts, an obvious difference could be observed as the Fe concentration in the MCF was increased from 4 to 12wt.%. The band that corresponds to surface hydroxyl groups is more intense for the catalyst with 12wt.% of Fe. The relatively high intensity of hydroxyl groups peaks suggested that large amount of hydroxyl groups was present on the surface of FeMCF12 [38]. It was deduced that, the introduction of Fe ions into MCF resulted in such changes that led to the absorption of more amounts of OH groups. Thus, it can be summarized that the increase in the Fe concentration incorporated into the MCF structure would directly enhance the intensity of peaks corresponding to surface hydroxyl that was formed during the hydrolysis reaction of TEOS in the aqueous solution as was suggested by Shukla et al [36] to positively improve the preferential adsorption behaviour of FeMCF. 3.2 Detection of OH by photoluminescence technique The influence of H2O2 decomposition over the catalysts (different in Fe concentration) was investigated and presented in Fig. 5 . The highest fluorescence intensity was attributed to the presence of FeMCF10 and it was then followed by FeMCF12, FeMCF8 and the lowest generation of OH was shown by FeMCF4. The presence of Fe plays a major role in producing OH as Fe can decompose H2O2 to form OOH and OH. Therefore, an increase in the Fe concentration distributed within the MCF structure could possibly enhance the formation of OH as high amount of active sites was readily available to interact with H2O2. However, a slightly different result was obtained in the present study as a significant decrease in the florescence peak was observed following the increase in Fe concentration from 10 to 12wt.%. This observation indicated that even though FeMCF12 contained the highest amount of Fe, it was still not able to generate sufficiently large amount of OH. The significant difference in the fluorescence intensity between FeMCF10 and FeMCF12 might be contributed by pore blockage and poor distribution of Fe as discussed previously. In addition, another possible cause could be due to the excess amount of Fe that resulted in the scavenging of OH [39]. Thus, it hindered the direct interaction with the addition of limited amount of H2O2 and induced the reduction in the high intensity of florescence peaks. 3.3 Performance of FeMCF catalysts 3.3.1 Adsorption study In Fenton-like process, the decrease in the dye concentration could be due to the adsorption of the dye onto the catalyst surface and/or the degradation of the dye by the generated of active radicals (OH and OOH). To determine the extent of surface adsorption prior to catalytic degradation, control experiments were conducted in the first 15min in the absence of H2O2 and the results are demonstrated in Fig. 6 (a). The highest adsorption of ARB was achieved by FeMCF12 (17%) and it was then followed by FeMCF10, FeMCF8 and FeMCF4 with 8%, 4% and 2%, respectively. As expected, no adsorption occurred in the case of MCF support (data not shown) to signify that Fe played the main role as active sites while MCF just provided a platform for Fe species to be dispersed on. In previous studies, Lachheb et al. [40] and Acosta-Silva et al. [34] pointed out that higher specific surface area and pore volume of catalyst gave much higher adsorption capabilities rather than lower surface area. This was due to the fact that larger surface area would have higher chances for metal dispersion and tendency to adsorb more dye molecules on the catalyst surface. However, the highest surface area possessed by FeMCF4 contributed only a minor role in the adsorption efficiency. Contrary, poor distribution of Fe on the external surface of FeMCF12 accompanied with the lowest surface area demonstrated the highest capability towards adsorbing the ARB. Based on this result, the highest adsorption of ARB on the catalyst surface was successfully attained by the catalyst that was synthesized with the addition of the highest concentration of Fe and did not necessary depend on the high surface area of catalyst solely. 3.3.2 Catalytic activity of FeMCF catalysts After 15min of adsorption, catalytic degradation of ARB was performed with the addition of H2O2 and the results are presented in Fig. 6(b). In the presence of H2O2 alone, a much slower reduction in the initial concentration of ARB occurred in which the differences at interval time of 5 and 60min were not significant. Moreover, complete removal of ARB still could not be achieved after 60min as longer reaction time might be needed to degrade all the ARB molecules. In contrast, a drastic reduction in the concentration of ARB to 80mg/L obviously occurred just after the addition of FeMCF4. Further increase in the amount of Fe to 8wt.% caused a dramatic reduction in the concentration of ARB from 100 to 0mg/L after 60min of reaction. By increasing the Fe loading to 10 and 12wt.%, significant enhancement towards the catalytic performance was observed as the degradation percentage achieved 100% efficiency for both catalysts. Generally, high concentration of Fe would increase the tendency of interaction between the active sites and reactants (H2O2 and ARB). This is because, the presence of significant amount of Fe active sites on the external surface of FeMCF12 (as demonstrated by SEM images and UV–vis DRS results) could play a significant role in adsorbing water molecules to form surface hydroxyl groups [41]. Therefore, the generation of OH could be enhanced to further promote the degradation process. However, it should be highlighted that even though the highest degradation efficiencies of ARB were demonstrated by both FeMCF10 and FeMCF12, a significant difference in the reduction of the ARB concentration was seen. It was clear that FeMCF12 was capable to reduce the ARB to 15mg/L in the first 10min of reaction compared to FeMCF10 which was only capable of reducing the concentration to 54mg/L in the same period. Thus, this result was rather contradictory to the results of photoluminescence techniques that have been discussed in the previous section. Even though the generation of OH by FeMCF12 was found to be significantly lower than FeMCF10 and even lower than FeMCF8, surprisingly it could perform faster reduction in the ARB concentration than FeMCF10 and FeMCF8. Thus, it was expected that the adsorption of ARB on FeMCF12 was rather dominant compared to the degradation process. In order to further confirm this statement, zeta potential analysis was conducted. For FeMCF4, the pHzpc was estimated to be 2.59 which was very close to pHzpc for pure silica (2.5). This could be due to the absence of active sites on the external surface of catalyst. Meanwhile, further increase in the Fe concentration into MCF caused slight increasing in the pHzpc values to 2.65, 3.3 and 3.5 for FeMCF8, FeMCF10 and FeMCF12, respectively. As the initial pH of ARB solution was 3.2, the tendency for FeMCF12 to be protonated was high due to the relatively higher value of pHzpc compared to the initial pH of ARB. So, the adsorption process was mainly governed by the strong electrostatic attraction between the positively charged of FeMCF12 and negatively charged of ARB anionic dye. As a result, more ARB anions would be easily adsorbed on the FeMCF surface compared to the other catalyst that had slightly lower and almost equal to initial pH of ARB solution. Thus, the external surface of FeMCF12 was expected have been covered with the adsorbed ARB to inhibit the interaction between Fe active sites and H2O2. Moreover, the available Fe active sites located within the pores could not be easily reached by the oxidant as they were blocked by the deposition of ARB molecules. Due to that reason, low amount of OH was generated to consequently affect the catalytic performance by slowing down the degradation process after 15min of reaction. For FeMCF10, the difference between the catalyst surface charge and initial pH of ARB solution was not significant. Therefore, the adsorption of ARB on the external surface of FeMCF10 was not severe compared to FeMCF12. Thus, the interaction between Fe active sites and H2O2 could occur in effective ways without any competition with the excessive adsorption of ARB molecules to consequently promote the generation of large amount of OH. Moreover, the H2O2 could also diffuse into the large pores of FeMCF10 to further react with the active sites that were mainly located inside them. For that reason, there was higher chance for the active sites to interact with H2O2, thus generating more amount of OH as proven in the photoluminescence analysis. Thus, it would directly enhance the degradation of ARB molecules existed on the external surface of catalyst and also in bulk solution. 3.3.3 Reaction rate constant and activation energy of the catalysts Plots of pseudo first order of ln (Co/C) vs. time and second order (1/Co-1/C) vs. time are shown in Fig. 6(c) and (d) and the values of k and R2 are tabulated in Table 2 . The results reveal that FeMCF with Fe concentrations of 4, 8 and 10wt.% concentration followed pseudo first order reaction kinetic with the values of R 2 close to 1. Accordingly, an increase in the Fe concentration from 4 to 10wt.% tremendously increase the reaction rate constant from 0.0308 to 0.0642min−1 to signify that the catalytic activity for ARB degradation was enhanced with an increase in the Fe dispersion within MCF structure. Moreover, it could also be correlated with the high surface area of FeMCF10 that could provide higher accessible active sites to interact with H2O2. However, when the Fe concentration reached 12wt.%, a decrease in the R 2 value (0.8942) was observed to indicate that the data did not fit the first order equation but rather more suitable for second order reaction with an R 2 value of 0.9266. According to a previous observation obtained by Natarajan et al. [38]. the adsorption of methylene blue on the catalyst surface followed pseudo second order kinetic to justify that higher preferential occurred due to the electrostatic interaction between the negatively charge of catalyst surface and positively charged methylene blue molecules. It could be justified that the pseudo second order reaction was caused by the chemisorption that occurred on the catalyst surface. The activation energy (Ea) of ARB degradation was determined by the rate constant k of the FeMCF10 at different temperatures (25, 30, 35 and 45°C) using Eq. (7). Where, A 0 is the Arrhenius factor, E a is the Arrhenius activation energy (kJ/mol), R is the gas constant (8.314 J/(mol K)) and T is the solution temperature (K). (7) ln k = − E a R T + ln A o Based on the results shown in Table 3 , the activation energy of FeMCF10 demonstrated 40.87kJ/mol. 3.3.4 Correlation between ARB decolourization, mineralization and mesopore surface area of the catalysts The extent of ARB mineralization was further investigated and the profiles of COD removal are presented in Fig. 6(e) in conjunction with the degradation percentage of ARB at 60min and mesopores surface area of all the developed catalysts. The result can be interpreted as a direct relationship between the increase in the Fe concentration towards the degradation efficiency of ARB while an indirect relationship towards the mesoporous surface area and percentage of COD removal. It could be seen that, negligible COD removal was obtained under the system of H2O2 alone as it was not capable of breaking down the ARB structure to result in poor COD removal of ARB. However, the use of FeMCF4 and FeMCF8 dramatically improved the COD removal to 61 and 80% corresponding to the degradation efficiencies of 97 and 99% for the respective catalyst. It should be noted that the mineralization of ARB shown by FeMCF4 was lower compared to those of the other catalysts and it might be due to the limited amount of Fe species available to minimize the interaction with the fixed amount of H2O2 added. Moreover, due to the slower regeneration of Fe2⁺ from Fe3⁺, the formation of OH was minimized. In fact, more OOH radicals were formed to give minimum effect on the degradation process as these radicals are not as effective as OH. Due to that reason, the requirement for large amount of OH arose not just to decolourise the ARB but also to further degrade the intermediates to achieve mineralization. For the case of FeMCF10 and FeMCF12, the difference in the percentage of COD removal could be noticed. It was found that FeMCF10 gave higher COD removal (99%) compared to FeMCF12 with only 68% which was even lower than that of FeMCF8 in 60min of reaction. The difference in the degradation and mineralization for FeMCF12 suggested that even though the catalyst was capable of degrading the colour of the dye, it did not necessary succeed to break the bond and mineralize the intermediate compounds. Similar conclusions were reported by Chen et al. [42] and Soon and Hameed [43] In this study, the reason might be due to the dominant contribution of adsorption of ARB on FeMCF12. Another possible reason could be due to an excess amount of Fe in FeMCF12 which might be in excess to react with a fixed amount of H2O2 added. Thus, instead of attacking the ARB, the generated of OH might also react with the excessive amount of Fe2⁺ to cause the formation of Fe3⁺ and OH and finally hampered the decolourisation and degradation rates. Moreover, isolated Fe in the FeMCF10 would allow easier interaction between the active sites with reactants without any severe pore blockage as compared to FeMCF12 (with the presence of crystalline iron oxide). Thus, the former was able to perform better catalytic and mineralization of ARB. Furthermore, this statement could be supported by the high mesopores surface area of FeMCF10 at 552m2/g while it was only 456m2/g for FeMCF12. Since the mesopores surface area for FeMCF10 was the highest coupled with large amount of Fe species, it would allow an easy interaction between the reactants and active sites to generate large amount of active radicals. 3.3.5 Reusability of the catalysts After the catalysts were utilized to degrade the targeted ARB, they were then separated from the treated solution by centrifugation. Without any drying or heat treatment process, the collected wet samples were washed with distilled water and reused for the degradation of ARB under the similar reaction conditions with the previous one. The same steps were repeated for up to 5 runs. Based on the results shown in Fig. 7 , it was found that the decompositions of ARB were rather fast in the first run for all the developed catalysts. However, further increase in the reaction process to the fifth run caused a detrimental reduction in the degradation efficiency for FeMCF4 and FeMCF8 in which the efficiency reduced to 84% and 85%, respectively. On the other hand, no significant loss of activity was observed for FeMCF10 and FeMCF12 under all five runs of recycle study which indicated the considerable stability of the FeMCF under the experimental conditions. FeMCF10 not just gave good performance in degradation efficiency but it also possessed good textural properties and lower Fe loading compared to FeMCF12. Therefore, it was selected for further study under various reaction conditions. 3.4 Catalytic performances of FeMCF10 under various reaction conditions 3.4.1 Effect of initial pH The solution pH plays an important role in the degradation of various types of organic dye as it could control the adsorption process and also affects the generation of OH [44]. Therefore, the trade-off between the catalytic performances, metal ions leaching and stability of the catalyst was investigated. Effect of initial pH on the degradation and COD removal of ARB as well as the amount of Fe that leached was investigated in the range from 2 to 6 and the results are shown in Fig. 8 (a). The increase in the initial pH of ARB from 2–4, and 6 significantly increased the degradation of ARB from 88 to 100 and decrease to 75 and 58%, respectively. Similar observation was seen for COD removal that increased from 87 to 100% at initial pH of 2 and 3, respectively. Improvements in the decolourization and COD removal efficiency of FeMCF10 were achieved after the pH was increased from 2 to 3 could be due to the enhancement in the generation of OH. As discussed in the previous section, when the initial pH of the solution (pH 2) was below the point zero charge of FeMCF10 (3.3), the competition between the ARB molecules and H2O2 to interact with the Fe species occurred. Thus, fewer amount of OH could be generated under this condition. Contrary, better decolourization efficiency achieved at an initial pH of 3 could be due to the effective interaction between Fe and H2O2 leading to the generation of sufficient amount of OH. On the other hand, at higher pH values (4 and 6) approaching neutral condition, relatively poor decolourisation and degradation efficiencies of organic dyes were observed compared to those in the acidic medium (pH∼2-3). One of the possible reasons could be related to the tendency of the catalyst to form less reactive OOH radicals rather than OH. In fact, an excess amount of OH available in the solution might lead to the formation of ferric hydroxide complexes that could possibly deactivate the catalyst [43]. At the same time, these Fe complexes could also reduce the reaction by preventing the interaction between the active sites and H2O2 [45] due to the high deposition of Fe hydroxide complexes on the surface of the catalyst. It should be noted that the amount of Fe that leached into the treated solution reduced accordingly with an increase in the initial pH of the solution. Almost no trace of Fe could be detected with initial pH of 4 and 6. Even though pH 3 was reported to cause high tendency for the Fe to leach into the treated solution [9]. a different observation was obtained in the current study as only 0.08mg/L was detected. Then, pH 3 was therefore selected for subsequent study as this condition gave the highest degradation and percentage of COD removal coupled with the reasonable Fe leaching. 3.4.2 Effect of H2O2 concentration The influence of H2O2 concentration on the degradation and COD removal of ARB was studied by adding low and high amounts of oxidant. Theoretically, 1mol of ARB requires about 59mol of H2O2, while 100mg/L of ARB require approximately 11mM of H2O2. A series of H2O2 concentrations (8, 11, 15 and 20mM) were tested for 40min and the results are shown in Fig. 8(b). When 8mM of H2O2 was added into the ARB solution which was below the requirement, only 81% of degradation was obtained accompanied with only 71% of COD removal. It should be noted that as the amount of H2O2 added was lower than the requirement, it only led to the generation of limited amount of OH. As a result, the degradation efficiency significantly decreased due to the limited amount of OH available to attack the targeted organic compounds in conjunction with the intermediate products. However, when the H2O2 amount was increased to 11 and 15mM, significant enhancements in the degradation efficiency and complete COD removal were observed. Logically, the increase in the addition of H2O2 into the solution significantly increases the generation of OH as more amount of H2O2 is available to be reacted with a fixed amount of Fe ions. As a consequence, the degradation and mineralization efficiencies are also improved due to the generation of large amount of OH. Surprisingly, when the amount of H2O2 was further increased up to 20mM, a slight reduction in the degradation performance was noticed. Similarly, Gao et al. [39] found that an excess amount of H2O2 beyond its optimum level led to the reduction in the degradation rate of rhodamine B to give almost similar removal with that of the lowest concentration of H2O2 added. This could be attributed by the radical scavenger caused by an excess amount of OH available leading to the formation of H2O2 and less active OOH radicals. Therefore, an appropriate amount of H2O2 should be added into the solution and possibly, the amount should be higher than that needed based on stoichiometry. More OH might be needed not just to degrade the organic pollutants but also to further react with the generated intermediate products. Moreover, it should be noted that the decolourisation of ARB was much easier than the mineralization process. Therefore, Queirós et al. [46] proposed that the amount of oxidant to be added into the solution to be higher than the stoichiometric dose as the H2O2 is also consumed in side reactions that do not produce OH. In order to achieve both decolourisation and mineralization at high efficiency and at the same time could prevent the occurrence of radical's scavenger and limitations of OH, 11mM of H2O2 was selected to be used for further study. 3.4.3 Effect of reaction temperature The effect of reaction temperature (32, 40 and 50°C) on the degradation and COD removal of ARB was investigated and the results are shown in Fig. 8(c). It could be observed that the temperature exerted a strong effect on the decolourisation rate of ARB. The increase in the reaction temperature from 32 to 50°C, significantly increased the decolourisation rate and Fe leaching into the treated solution. At a reaction temperature of 50°C, only 10min was required to achieved fully decolourisation of ARB while further decrease in the temperature to 40°C, a slightly longer reaction time was required to get complete decolourisation of ARB which was 15min. The lowest decolourisation efficiency was achieved at a reaction temperature of 32°C in which 30min of reaction time was required in conjunction with the lowest amount of Fe leaching which was about 0.03mg/L. The high decolourisation and degradation rates at high temperature could be related to the generation of large amount of OH comparable to the reaction under lower temperature due to the higher effective collision of H2O2 and active sites. The generated OH would collide more frequently with the dye molecules to result in the degradation to smaller and less harmful compounds [43]. Even though high decolourisation and degradation efficiencies are widely reported at high reaction temperature, it should be noted that, the probability for the metal to leach out from the support material can also increase at high reaction temperature. Therefore, the reaction temperature of 32°C was chosen as the right level as it could enhance the decolourisation efficiencies but at the same time could avoid the excessive leaching of metal species into the treated solution which would consequently affect the stability and reusability of the catalyst. 3.5 Reaction mechanism of FeMCF10/H2O2/ARB system From the experimental results, it is evident that FeMCF10 catalyst managed to decompose ARB into colourless fragments in the initial stages and subsequently mineralize the dye into harmless end products as proven by the highest reduction in the COD value. Besides minor adsorption of ARB on the catalyst surface, the quick decrease of ARB concentration in the presence of FeMCF10 could be due to catalytic destruction of ARB by the generated OH. The reaction is basically started with H2O2 adsorption on the catalyst surface to react with the Fe active sites that are situated on the catalyst surface (Equation 8 and 9). It could also diffuse into the mesochannels to interact further with the Fe sites located within the MCF structure or along the short mesochannels to consequently generate the OH. Under acidic medium, there might be some possibilities for the Fe to be leached out into the solution (Eqs. (10) and (11)) which could generate OH based on homogeneous reaction (Eq. (13)). (8) Fe 3 + + H 2 O 2 → F e 2 + + O O H + H + (9) Fe 2 + + H 2 O 2 → F e 3 + + O H + −OH (10) F e 3 + + H + → Fe 3 + (11) Fe 2 + + H + → Fe 2 + (12) Fe 3 + + H 2 O 2 → Fe 2 + + O O H + H + (13) Fe 2 + + H 2 O 2 → Fe 3 + + O H + −H + Comparisons between the performances of FeMCF10 with recent heterogeneous catalysts reported for Fenton-based catalyst are tabulated in Table 4 . It can be summarized that the combined factors such as high surface area of 671m2/g (with 552m2/g of mesopore area), large cell and window size (8 and 4nm), isolated iron species presence, good dispersion of metal species within the support structure and the high capability of the catalyst to generate large amount of OH might be the reasons for the FeMCF10 to exhibit the highest degradation and mineralization performance. 3.6 Reusability and stability studies of FeMCF10 The reusability potential and stability of FeMCF10 were investigated for 5 runs of recycle and the results are shown in Fig. 9 (a). In the meantime, the COD and TOC removals of ARB for the reusability study in conjunction with the detection of the Fe leached into the treated solution are presented in Fig. 9(b). Even after 5 runs of repeated uses, FeMCF10 could still maintain its high catalytic activity in which no significant decrease in the degradation efficiency could be noticed from run 1 to run 5. The good performance of FeMCF10 was not just limited to the decolourisation efficiency only but also on the decreasing values of COD which was maintained at more than 95% after the fifth run of reaction. In fact, this catalyst also showed a reasonably high percentage of TOC removal and the performance could be maintained without significant reduction for up to 5 runs. The complete degradation of ARB was further confirmed by the disappearances of ARB peaks as shown in Fig. 10 . By comparing the fresh ARB peaks, the peak intensities of the azo bond (NN) at 1501cm−1 and the benzene ring (1430–1600cm−1) of ARB decrease even after being reused for 5 runs. The results indicated the disappearance of both the parental dye and its primary aromatic breakdown products [47]. In fact, it could be seen that the peaks at 1190 and 1279cm−1 corresponded to sulfonate groups were disappeared and a formation of small peak at 1127cm−1 could indicate that the dye was successfully destroyed [48]. To prove the stability of the FeMCF10 after 5 consecutive cycles, FT-IR spectra were taken for the spent catalysts and the results are shown in Fig. 11 . By comparing the spent catalysts after being used at 1st, 3rd and 5th runs with the fresh one (Fig. 4), no obvious changes could be observed. This is to indicate that the FeMCF10 could maintain their high performance and stability even after being used for many runs. To further investigate the effect of the degradation process on the mesopore structure of FeMCF10, TEM analysis was conducted for the catalyst in run 1, run 3 and run 5. As shown in Fig. 12 , the mesostructure of FeMCF10 could still be preserved as compared with the original one as shown in Fig. 1(g) as no significant changes or structural damages were seen. Thus, this observation could provide the evidence for the high stability of FeMCF10. 4 Conclusions The characteristics and catalytic performance of Fe incorporated MCF catalyst were affected significantly by the addition of various Fe concentrations. An increase in the Fe concentration from 4 to 10wt.% had a great influence on the surface characteristics and Fe dispersion. The Fe species were found to be distributed evenly on and within the MCF structure at Fe concentrations between of 4–10wt.%. Further increase to 12wt.% led to the formation of rather coarse particles deposited on the external surface of the catalyst. However, the mesostructure of the developed catalysts at all Fe concentrations was not significantly altered and they could maintain the large pore and uniform structure of MCF with the appearance of Fe species within it. Among the catalysts tested, FeMCF10 showed the highest degradation efficiency (100%) of ARB coupled with the lowest leaching of Fe (<0.06mg/L) into the treated solution and the highest COD removal (99%). Combined factors including high mesopore surface area (552m2/g), large cell and window size (8 and 4nm), presence of isolated iron species, good dispersion of metal species within the support structure and the high capability of the catalyst to generate large amount of OH might be the reasons for the FeMCF10 to exhibit the highest degradation and mineralization efficiencies. In fact, FeMCF10 did not experience significant reduction in the decolourisation activity and percentage of COD removal when reused for up to 5 times. Therefore, Fe incorporated MCF prepared by direct synthesis method was a promising alternative to tackle the problems related to metal leaching and catalyst stability and useful for efficient degradation and mineralization of organic pollutants in water. coredata.dc:description: Fe incorporated mesocellular foam catalysts (FeMCFs) developed by direct synthesis method were characterized and catalytic degradation of acid red B dye (ARB) via Fenton-like reaction was demonstrated. The shape and particle sizes of FeMCF changed significantly with an increase in the Fe concentration (4–12wt.%) accompanied with the formation of Fe particles agglomerated on the external surface of the catalysts. Interestingly, the sponge-like foam structure coupled with large pores of MCF could be maintained for all concentrations of Fe added. FT-IR and UV–vis DRS analyses revealed that Fe was successfully incorporated mostly within the mesostructure of MCF rather than being distributed on the external surface at Fe loadings of 4–10wt.%. However, formation of minor amount of iron oxides distributed on the external surface of FeMCF12 was detected by the appearance of broad bands in the range of 300–400nm. An increase in the Fe content (4–12wt.%) gave a slight decrease in the surface area (708–606m2/g) and pore properties of the FeMCF. The increase in the Fe concentration from 4 to 12wt.% progressively increased the degradation from 63 to 100%. The high decolourisation and degradation efficiencies of FeMCF10 could be explained in terms of combined factors such as high mesopore surface area (552m2/g), large cell size (8nm) and the presence of isolated Fe species leading to high accessibility of active sites without mass transfer limitations. FeMCF10 exhibited long term stability and good structural stability after it was used for five consecutive degradation cycles.
coredata.dc:title: Fe incorporated mesocellular foam as an effective and stable catalyst: Effect of Fe concentration on the characteristics and activity in Fenton-like oxidation of acid red B
